extendedIngredients.name: napa cabbage
extendedIngredients.original: 4 cups (1/2 pound) coarsely shredded Napa cabbage

extendedIngredients.name: snow peas
extendedIngredients.original: 6 ounces snow peas, sliced into half-inch slices on the diagonal
extendedIngredients.originalName: snow peas, sliced into half-inch slices on the diagonal
meta: sliced into half-inch slices on the diagonal

extendedIngredients.name: green onions
extendedIngredients.original: 2/3 cup thinly sliced green onions (including greens)

extendedIngredients.name: rice vinegar
extendedIngredients.original: 1 tablespoon plus 1 1/2 teaspoons rice vinegar (seasoned or unseasoned)

extendedIngredients.name: garlic
extendedIngredients.original: 1/2 clove peeled and minced garlic (about 1/2 teaspoon)

title: Napa Cabbage Picnic Salad
summary: Napa Cabbage Picnic Salad is a gluten free, dairy free, and lacto ovo vegetarian hor d'oeuvre. One portion of this dish contains about 5g of protein, 26g of fat, and a total of 297 calories. This recipe serves 4 and costs $1.88 per serving. 80 people have made this recipe and would make it again. This recipe from Simply Recipes requires slivered almonds, sugar, rice vinegar, and radishes. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 20 minutes. Overall, this recipe earns a very bad (but still fixable) spoonacular score of 0%. If you like this recipe, take a look at these similar recipes: Asian Napa Cabbage Carrot Salad (Picnic for the Planet 2012 Giveaway), Napa Picnic, and Napa Cabbage Salad.

winePairing.pairingText: Salad works really well with Chardonnay, Gruener Veltliner, and Sauvignon Blanc. Sauvignon Blanc and Gruner Veltliner both have herby notes that complement salads with enough acid to match tart vinaigrettes, while a Chardonnay can be a good pick for creamy salad dressings. The Aubert Lauren Vineyard Chardonnay with a 4.4 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 139 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Aubert Lauren Vineyard Chardonnay
productMatches.description: The 2011 Lauren Estate Chardonnay always reminds one of a hypothetical vintage blend of Sonoma Coast meets White Burgundy. This 2011 Lauren is naturally clear with green chlorophyll tints on edge. Aromatics are classic Lauren with nuances of lemon-mineral, dried pear and even some green tea-like tones. The pronounced aromatics of fruits and minerals give an organic sense of place. The bouquet is multi-faceted with hints of apple-baked goods and wet stones. The mouth feel presents a glycerin top note, followed by an acid structure only found at Lauren.The wine has a slight hazy clarity showing Aubert's commitment to minimal interventional winemaking.

instructions:
Toast the almonds: Toast the almond slivers in a dry nonstick or cast-iron skillet on medium high, stirring frequently until browned. Set aside.

Assemble the salad ingredients: Combine cabbage, snow peas, radishes, green onions, cilantro in a large bowl. Can make this step a day or two ahead.

Make the dressing: In a separate bowl, whisk together the rice vinegar, sugar, soy sauce, garlic, sesame oil, ginger, and cayenne until sugar has dissolved. Whisk in the mayonnaise.

Toss the salad with dressing: When ready to serve, gently combine the dressing and almonds with the cabbage mixture.

steps.step: Toast the almonds: Toast the almond slivers in a dry nonstick or cast-iron skillet on medium high, stirring frequently until browned. Set aside.
Combine cabbage, snow peas, radishes, green onions, cilantro in a large bowl. Can make this step a day or two ahead.
Make the dressing: In a separate bowl, whisk together the rice vinegar, sugar, soy sauce, garlic, sesame oil, ginger, and cayenne until sugar has dissolved.
Toss the salad with dressing: When ready to serve, gently combine the dressing and almonds with the cabbage mixture.
